case_name: Podar Plastics P Ltd. v. its workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 496 of 1963 filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 496,of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Award dated August 26, 1961 of Industrial Tribunal Maharashtra in Reference IT No. 43 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave front the Award dated August 26, 1961, of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra in Reference  IT  No. 43 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 19, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: December 19, 1963.-The Judgment of the Court was ,delivered by- GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-This appeal arises from an, Industrial dispute

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellant Podar Plastics Pvt Ltd and respondents its workmen regarding bonus for 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from an, Industrial dispute between the appellant Podar Plastics  P  Ltd. and the respondents, its workmen, and it has reference ,to the claim made by the respondents for bonus for the year 1959.

facts.text: Respondents claimed bonus equivalent to three months salary including dearness allowance for 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claim that for the relevant year they -should get bonus equivalent to three months salary includ- ing dearness allowance.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal awarded bonus at rate of half months basic wages excluding allowances and overtime for 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On hearing the parties and on company- sidering the evidence adduced by them, the Tribunal has ,directed that the appellant shall pay to the respondents bonus at the rate of half months basic wages excluding ,allowances and overtime for the said year.

facts.text: Appellant owns factory at Supari Baug Road where it manufactures plastic products.

anchor.surface_text: It owns a factory at Supari Baug Road where it manufactures plastic products.

facts.text: Gross profit figure admitted at Rs. 2.70 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: The figure of the profit was. admitted at Rs. 2.70 lacs.

facts.text: Tribunal calculated available surplus Rs. 0.44 lac using statutory depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: On the first calculation the available. surplus was found to be Rs. 0. 44 lac.

facts.text: Tribunal calculated available surplus Rs. 0.33 lac using commercial depreciation claimed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the alternative calculation, it was found to be Rs. 0.33 lac.

facts.text: Court accepts surplus calculation of Rs. 0.33 lac but notes mistakes correcting to Rs. 0.39 lac.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal we will accept the latter calculation which is made on the basis that the numberional numbermal depreciation has to be deducted. It has been companyceded before us by the learned Addl. Solicitor-General for the appellant that there are two mis- takes in this calculation.

facts.text: Appellant claimed deduction of Rs. 60,000 as notional remuneration for Mr. K. R. Podar.

anchor.surface_text: The main point which has been urged before us by the learned Addl. Solicitor-General relates to the claim made by the appellant for the deduction as a prior charge of Rs. 60,000 by way of numberional remuneration for Mr. K. R. Podar

facts.text: Appellant is private limited company with major shareholders R.A. Podar, G.R. Podar, K.R. Podar, B.J. Podar, Ms. Podar Trading Co. Pvt Ltd., Jay Agents Pvt Ltd., National Traders Pvt Ltd., Ratilal B. Desai.

anchor.surface_text: We have already seen that the appellant is a Private Ltd. Co. and four of the major shareholders are members of the Podar family they are R.A. Podar, G.R. Podar, K.R. Podar and B.J. Podar the 5th shareholder is M s. Podar Trading Co. Private Ltd., 6th is Jay Agents Private Ltd., 7th is the National Traders Private Ltd. and the 8th is Ratilal B. Desai.

facts.text: K.R. Podar devoted whole time to supervision and management, claimed entitled to Rs. 5,000 per month remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, K.R. Podar devoted the whole of his time to the supervision and management of the appellant companycern, and so, he was entitled to charge remuneration at the rate of Rs. 5,000 a month.

facts.text: Mr. Gupta, Manager of company, made affidavit supporting Podar remuneration claim and offered for cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: In sup- port of this claim, Mr. Gupta, the Manager of the companycern, made an affidavit and offered himself for cross-examination.

facts.text: K.R. Podar attends factory from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 2:30 P.M. to 6:30 P.M.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that Mr. Podar attends the factory from 9 A.M. to 1 P.m. and 2-30 P.m. to 6-30 P.m.

facts.text: No board resolution passed for remuneration of K.R. Podar unlike previous director who was paid Rs. 1000 per month.

anchor.surface_text: In his cross-examination, it was brought out that when the previous Director was paid Rs. 1000 per month as remuneration, a resolution had been passed by the Board of Directors in that behalf but numbersuch resolution has been passed in regard to the remuneration of Mr. K. R. Podar.

facts.text: K.R. Podar did not actually charge any remuneration due to unsatisfactory financial position of company.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the appellant itself has urged that Mr. Podar did number actually charge any remuneration because it was thought that the financial position of the appellant was number very satisfactory

facts.text: Tribunal did not allow deduction for notional remuneration of K.R. Podar.

anchor.surface_text: Relying on these decisions, it is urged on behalf of the appellant that the Tribunal was in error in number allowing any deduction on account of remuneration to Mr. Podar.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected appellant's claim for rehabilitation of Rs. 8,84,629.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that one of the reasons given by the Tribunal is that the  1  appellant is number justified in making a claim for rehabilita- tion on the basis that new machinery would be purchased by him for rehabilitating his old one

facts.text: Appellant began business with second-hand machinery.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Tribunal was inclined to take the view that since the appellant had begun its business with second-hand machinery

facts.text: Evidence by Mr. Dinshaw for rehabilitation claim not accepted by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: but there are several other reasons which the Tribunal has discussed and these reasons indicate that the Tribunal was number satisfied with the accuracy of the statements made by Mr. Dinshaw and their reliability.

facts.text: No material to determine wealth tax amount paid or charged.

anchor.surface_text: but, in the present case, there is numbermaterial to determine what the amount of wealth tax charged or paid is, and so, numberrelief can be granted to the appellant on that account.
Appeal by special leave front the Award dated August 26, 1961, of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra in Reference  IT  No. 43 of 1961.
It is against this ,award that the appellant has come to this Court by special leave.

The appellants case before the Tribunal was that if proper accounts are made in accordance with the Full Bench Formula, it would be found that there is noavailable surplus from which any bonus can be paid to the respondents.

concepts.interpretation: Formula applied to compute available surplus from gross profits after deducting prior charges like depreciation, remuneration, rehabilitation, and taxes to determine bonus payable.

holdings.text: Court accepts the calculation of available surplus based on notional normal depreciation rather than statutory depreciation, correcting it to Rs. 0.39 lac.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal we will accept the latter calculation which is made on the basis that the notional normal depreciation has to be deducted. It has been conceded before us by the learned Addl. Solicitor-General for the appellant that there are two mis- takes in this calculation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts appellant's claimed notional depreciation as basis for calculation, notes Tribunal errors favoring appellant, arrives at Rs. 0.39 lac surplus.

holdings.text: There is available surplus of Rs. 0.39 lac under Full Bench Formula after prior charges.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal we will accept the latter calculation which is made on the basis that the notional normal depreciation has to be deducted. It has been conceded before us by the learned Addl. Solicitor-General for the appellant that there are two mis- takes in this calculation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corrects Tribunal's alternative calculation using notional depreciation and conceded errors to find surplus exists.

holdings.text: Appellant not entitled to deduct Rs. 60,000 as prior charge for notional remuneration of Mr. K.R. Podar.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appellant cannot seriously quarrel with the finding of the Tribunal, because it is conceded that Mr. Podar in fact has not charged any remuneration. The working of the Formula is no doubt notional in some respects, but we think it would not be permissible for the employer to make it still more notional by introducing claims for prior charges on purely hypothetical and almost fictional basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Remuneration not actually charged, hypothetical claim impermissible to depress surplus; Tribunal rejected evidence including lack of Podar's testimony and no board resolution; precedents distinguish actual payments.

holdings.text: Employer cannot introduce purely hypothetical and fictional prior charges in notional Full Bench Formula working.

anchor.surface_text: The working of the Formula is no doubt notional in some respects, but we think it would not be permissible for the employer to make it still more notional by introducing claims for prior charges on purely hypothetical and almost fictional basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formula already notional; hypothetical claims undermine purpose of surplus allocation.

holdings.text: Director entitled to reasonable remuneration as prior charge if actually paid and shown in accounts, subject to scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: If Mr. Podar had been paid remuneration regularly and it had been duly shown in the books of account, a claim in that behalf would have been made by the appellant, and subject to the scrutiny by the Industrial Tribunal as to reasonableness of the said payment, such a claim would have been allowed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical if not actual; relies on precedents like Gujarat Engineering and Kodaneri Estate for actual reasonable payments.

holdings.text: Tribunal's approach to rehabilitation erroneous: replacement by new machinery even if existing second-hand.

anchor.surface_text: This view has been rejected by this Court in the case of South India Millowners Association and Ors. v. Coimbatore District Textile Workers Union and Ors. Therefore, the appellant is right in contending that the approach adopted by the Tribunal in dealing with the question of rehabilitation is erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in South India Millowners rejecting second-hand replacement basis.

holdings.text: Appellant not entitled to rehabilitation claim as Tribunal rejected evidence of Mr. Dinshaw on reliability grounds.

anchor.surface_text: That, however, does not help the appellant because in the present case the Tribunal has considered the evidence given by Mr. Dinshaw on behalf of the appellant In support of its claim that the rehabilitation requirement of the appellant would be of the order of Rs. -8,84,629. ... In the result, the finding of the Tribunal is based on its appreciation of the evidence led by the appellant and that cannot be disturbed having regard to the material which is available on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds Tribunal's evidence appreciation; cannot disturb findings; future better evidence allowed.

holdings.text: No ad hoc rehabilitation allowance without sufficient evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It would, we think, be erroneous to assume that this Court approved of or affirmed the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal in that particular case. On what material the said ad hoc basis was adopted is not known, and it would, we think, be unreasonable to suggest that if the employer does not adduce sufficient evidence to justify his claim for rehabilitation and the Tribunal is inclined to reject the evidence which has been adduced, the Tribunal must nevertheless award some rehabilitation on a purely hypothetical and imaginary ad hoc basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes South India Millowners where evidence existed; rejects hypothetical ad hoc without evidence.

holdings.text: Employer entitled to deduct wealth tax as prior charge in bonus calculations if material shows amount charged or paid.

anchor.surface_text: It has been consistently held by this Court that in bonus calculations the employer is entitled to claim a deduction of the income-tax as well as wealth tax but, in the present case, there is no material to determine what the amount of wealth tax charged or paid is, and so, no relief can be granted to the appellant on that account.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent precedent allows deduction but no material here to quantify.

justification_sets.label: Prior Charges in Bonus Formula support

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. Solicitor-General, however, attempted to argue that the Tribunal should have made some allowance for rehabilitation on an ad hoc basis and in support of this companytention, he has referred us to some of the observations made in the case of South India Millowners Association  1 . It appears that in that case, the appellant Mills had number adduced relevant evidence about the original price and subsequent depreciation of the machinery prior to its purchase by the appellant, and so, acting on the evidence available on the record, the Tribunal adopted some  id hoc basis. No grievance was made about the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal the only grievance made was against certain observations made by the Tribunal that if the existing machinery is second hand.

outcome.relief_summary: No relief granted to appellant; all claims for prior deductions (notional remuneration to director, rehabilitation, wealth tax) rejected; Tribunal's award of bonus at half month's basic wages excluding allowances and overtime upheld
directions: If the appellant leads better evidence in future, its claim for rehabilitation would have to be judged on the merits and the present decision will not create any bar against it

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal we will accept the latter calculation which is made on the basis that the notional normal depreciation has to be deducted. It has been conceded before us by the learned Addl. Solicitor-General for the appellant that there are two mis- takes in this calculation.

In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. Solicitor-General, however, attempted to argue that the Tribunal should have made some allowance for rehabilitation on an ad hoc basis and in support of this companytention, he has referred us to some of the observations made in the case of South India Millowners Association  1 . It appears that in that case, the appellant Mills had number adduced relevant evidence about the original price and subsequent depreciation of the machinery prior to its purchase by the appellant, and so, acting on the evidence available on the record, the Tribunal adopted some  id hoc basis. No grievance was made about the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal the only grievance made was against certain observations made by the Tribunal that if the existing machinery is second hand.

In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appellant cannot seriously quarrel with the finding of the Tribunal, because it is conceded that Mr. Podar in fact has not charged any remuneration. The working of the Formula is no doubt notional in some respects, but we think it would not be permissible for the employer to make it still more notional by introducing claims for prior charges on purely hypothetical and almost fictional basis.

In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. Solicitor-General, however, attempted to argue that the Tribunal should have made some allowance for rehabilitation on an ad hoc basis and in support of this companytention, he has referred us to some of the observations made in the case of South India Millowners Association  1 . It appears that in that case, the appellant Mills had number adduced relevant evidence about the original price and subsequent depreciation of the machinery prior to its purchase by the appellant, and so, acting on the evidence available on the record, the Tribunal adopted some  id hoc basis. No grievance was made about the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal the only grievance made was against certain observations made by the Tribunal that if the existing machinery is second hand.

anchor.surface_text: This view has been rejected by this Court in the case of South India Millowners Association and Ors. v. Coimbatore District Textile Workers Union and Ors. Therefore, the appellant is right in contending that the approach adopted by the Tribunal in dealing with the question of rehabilitation is erroneous.

In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. Solicitor-General, however, attempted to argue that the Tribunal should have made some allowance for rehabilitation on an ad hoc basis and in support of this companytention, he has referred us to some of the observations made in the case of South India Millowners Association  1 . It appears that in that case, the appellant Mills had number adduced relevant evidence about the original price and subsequent depreciation of the machinery prior to its purchase by the appellant, and so, acting on the evidence available on the record, the Tribunal adopted some  id hoc basis. anchor.surface_text: That, however, does not help the appellant because in the present case the Tribunal has considered the evidence given by Mr. Dinshaw on behalf of the appellant In support of its claim that the rehabilitation requirement of the appellant would be of the order of Rs. -8,84,629. ... In the result, the finding of the Tribunal is based on its appreciation of the evidence led by the appellant and that cannot be disturbed having regard to the material which is available on the record.

In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. Solicitor-General, however, attempted to argue that the Tribunal should have made some allowance for rehabilitation on an ad hoc basis and in support of this companytention, he has referred us to some of the observations made in the case of South India Millowners Association  1 . It appears that in that case, the appellant Mills had number adduced relevant evidence about the original price and subsequent depreciation of the machinery prior to its purchase by the appellant, and so, acting on the evidence available on the record, the Tribunal adopted some  id hoc basis. No grievance was made about the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal the only grievance made was against certain observations made by the Tribunal that if the existing machinery is second hand.

anchor.surface_text: It would, we think, be erroneous to assume that this Court approved of or affirmed the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal in that particular case. On what material the said ad hoc basis was adopted is not known, and it would, we think, be unreasonable to suggest that if the employer does not adduce sufficient evidence to justify his claim for rehabilitation and the Tribunal is inclined to reject the evidence which has been adduced, the Tribunal must nevertheless award some rehabilitation on a purely hypothetical and imaginary ad hoc basis.

In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. Solicitor-General, however, attempted to argue that the Tribunal should have made some allowance for rehabilitation on an ad hoc basis and in support of this companytention, he has referred us to some of the observations made in the case of South India Millowners Association  1 . It appears that in that case, the appellant Mills had number adduced relevant evidence about the original price and subsequent depreciation of the machinery prior to its purchase by the appellant, and so, acting on the evidence available on the record, the Tribunal adopted some  id hoc basis. No grievance was made about the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal the only grievance made was against certain observations made by the Tribunal that if the existing machinery is second hand.

anchor.surface_text: It has been consistently held by this Court that in bonus calculations the employer is entitled to claim a deduction of the income-tax as well as wealth tax but, in the present case, there is no material to determine what the amount of wealth tax charged or paid is, and so, no relief can be granted to the appellant on that account.

In our opinion, that is all that can be done in the present appeal. The learned Addl. Solicitor-General, however, attempted to argue that the Tribunal should have made some allowance for rehabilitation on an ad hoc basis and in support of this companytention, he has referred us to some of the observations made in the case of South India Millowners Association  1 . It appears that in that case, the appellant Mills had number adduced relevant evidence about the original price and subsequent depreciation of the machinery prior to its purchase by the appellant, and so, acting on the evidence available on the record, the Tribunal adopted some  id hoc basis. No grievance was made about the ad hoc basis adopted by the Tribunal the only grievance made was against certain observations made by the Tribunal that if the existing machinery is second hand.
